One Word more I have to ſay, 'Tis reported I have been hired and Suborn'd, I do admire why this City of London, where there are as worthy men, and as great Lovers of the King and Government as any in the World, ſhould ſay any ſuch thing; I was never Suborn'd by them, nor never took a farthing of their money, nor never took a farthing of the King in my life.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who ſuppoſes it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: 'Tis in print, my Lord, 'twas in the Book that came out laſt night, it is ſuppos'd, my Lord, for it is in print.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I had reaſon to expect that there was no ſuch objection.

div.p: Brian Haines.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sanders.
sp.p: Give your knowledge of what diſcourſe you have heard concerning my Lord Shaftsbury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haines.
sp.p: Sir, I have heard him Villifie the King very often, and he told me about the Narrative that I made about Sir Edmond-Bury Godfrey's death, Mr. Ivey and I went to him one day and he ſpoke to me of it, and I deſired him not to expoſe my perſon to the King's Anger, for I was ſure he would never grant a pardon to any man that impeached the Earl of Danby. Say's he, Do not fear, if he doth not grant you a pardon, he makes himſelf the Author of the Plot; and▪ ſay's he, the Earl of Eſſex; my Lord Maxfield and I, wee do all reſolve if you put in writing, we will go to the King, and beg a pardon of his Majeſty for you, and if he doth not grant it, we will raiſe the whole Kingdom againſt him; for, ſay's he, he muſt not expect to live peaceably in his Throne, if he doth not grant it. For he makes himſelf author of the Plot.

My Lord, ſaid I, he hath diſſolved ſo many Parliaments for the ſake of the Earl of Danby, and prorogued ſo many Parliaments, therefore he will never grant me this Pardon. Say's he, doe not fear, 'tis the beſt pretence we can have in the world, and if you will but put in writing, and let me read it, that I may give my opinion of it, the work is done; and if he doth not do it, we are prepar'd to raiſe Arms againſt him. I was with him another time after I made this Narrative, and he told me the two Mr. Godfrey's were with the King at Windſor, and begged a pardon of his Majeſty for me, but the King would not grant it, but if he be an honeſt man, let him lye at my mercy, let him come in and declare what he knows. Said I, I would not have your Lordſhip expoſe my cauſe in theſe day's. This is the beſt time for it in the world, ſay's he, if he doth not do it, he can't expect to be long King of England. Pray my Lord ſaid I, what ſhall I do in the mean time? I will go beyond▪ Sea, ſaid I. No, ſayes he, don't leave the Kingdom, he dares as well be hang'd as meddle with you. I deſir'd him a ſecond time not to expoſe me to the King's fury, and I prayed him to help me to a little money to go beyond Sea, for I was ſure I could not be ſafe in England. Sayes he, Have a care of your ſelf; but, ſayes he, he dares as well be hang'd as meddle with you. Then I was in cloſe conference with him one day, and I gave him ſo exact an account of all Tranſactions from King Charles the Firſt's Reign, the commencement or coming to the Crown to this very day, that he was mightily ſatisfied, finding by me that I was a Traveller, he was mightily pleaſed, and free with me. Pray my Lord, what Model do you take, or intend to do? Sayes he, Do you not think but there are Families in England, that have as great pretences to the Crown as the King? Sayes he, there is the Duke of Bucks in the right of his Mother, ſhe was deſcended from Edward, one of the Edwards, and in her Right he claimes the Barony of Roſs, he hath as great a Right to the Crown of England, as ever any Stewart of them all.

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Speak that again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haines.
sp.p: I was in Conference with my Lord Shaftsbury one day, and I gave him an exact account of all Tranſactions, and I asked what they did intend to do with the Government, if they pull'd the King down. Sayes he, Do you think there are no Families in England, that have as much pretence to the Crown as any of the Stewarts? I know none my Lord, ſayes he, there is the Duke of Bucks that is deſcended of the Family of the Plantagenets; he named ſome of the Edwards, and in her right he ſhould have the Barony of Roſs, and in her Right he has as good a Title to the Crown of England as ever any Stewart had.

div.p: John Macnamarra Sworn.

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: Pray give an account to the Jury of what diſcourſe you have had with my Lord Shaftsbury.

sp.speaker: John Macnamarra.
sp.p: My Lord, I was with my Lord Shaftsbury a little before he went to Oxford, before the Parliament ſat there, and my Lord told me at that time, that he would take care, together with thoſe that were with him at Oxford, for the Witneſſes that were concerned in the Popiſh Plot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Harriſon.
sp.p: Speak out pray Sir.

sp.speaker: John Macnamarra.
sp.p: My Lord told me he would take care, with thoſe that were with him, for the Witneſſes that were concern'd in the Popiſh Plot; after my Lord went to Oxford, I writ him a Letter, giving his Lordſhip to underſtand, That whereas his Lordſhip was pleaſed to promiſe, that he would take care of the Witneſſes, that he would be pleaſed to take care of me, as well as the reſt of the Witneſſes; after my Lord came home from Oxford, I went to him, to ſee what was done. His Lordſhip was pleaſed to expreſs himſelf and ſay, That the King was Popiſhly affected and did adhere to Popery, and that he took the ſame methods that his Father before him took, which brought his Father's Head to the block, and we will alſo bring his thither; and told me alſo, That he told ſome Perſons of Quality that this would fall out Five years before; at the ſame time my Lord told me, That there was a Collection of Money made, and that the meeting was at the Sun Tavern, and that there came a Tory Lord in to hinder their proceedings, but ſayes he, we do remove to Iron-monger-Lane, and ſayes he, you ſhall hear further in a fortnight. I came to my Lord a fortnight afterwards, and his Lordſhip was pleaſed to tell me, that there was proviſion made for the Witneſſes, and that it was in the hand of one Mr. Rowſe that was Servant to Sir Thomas Player; there was one Mr. Ivey, and I think my Brother was by too, when his Lordſhip ſpake theſe words; he ſaid that the King was a Faithleſsman, that there was no Credit to be given to him, and that the Dutcheſs of Mazarine was his Cabinet Council, who was the worſt of Woman-kind. This is all that I have to ſay, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: Do you remember nothing at any other time?

sp.speaker: John Macnamarra.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing about depoſing the King?

sp.speaker: John Macnamarra.
sp.p: Yes, he did at the ſame time ſay, the King deſerved to be depoſed as much as ever King Richard the Second did.

div.p: Dennis Macnamarra.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sanders.
sp.p: Tell theſe Gentlemen whether you have had any diſcourſe with the Earl of Shaftsbury.

sp.speaker: Dennis Macnamarra.
sp.p:
He ſaid, my Lord, that the King was a man that ought not to be believed, and there was no belief in him, and that he ought
to be depoſed as well as King Richard the Second, and that the Dutcheſs of Mazarine was one of his Cabinet Council, and that he did nothing but by her Advice.

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: Begin again.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Raiſe your voice a little, for the Jury don't hear you.

sp.speaker: Dennis Macnamarra.
sp.p: That the King is a man that ought not to be believed, that there was no belief in him, and that he ought to be depoſed as well as King Richard the 2d. and that the Dutcheſs of Mazarine was his Cabinet Council, and that he did nothing but by her conſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was with you at that time?

sp.speaker: Dennis Macnamarra.
sp.p: There was Mr. Ivey, and my Brother at his own Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Dennis Macnamarra.
sp.p: 'Twas at the latter end of March or the beginning of April.

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: You ſay Mr. Ivey was by at the ſame time?

sp.speaker: Dennis Macnamarra.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: Call Mr. Ivey.

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: What place was it in?

sp.speaker: D. Macnamarra.
sp.p: In his own houſe.

div.p: Edward Ivey ſworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey.
sp.p: My Lord, ſoon after the Parliament was diſſolv'd at Oxford, I was at my Lord Shaftsbury's houſe, where he was ſpeaking againſt the King, and ſaid, that he was an unjuſt man, and unfit to Reign, and that he was a Papiſt in his heart, and would introduce Popery.

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Say that again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey.
sp.p:
I tell you I was at my Lord Shaftsbury's houſe, where he was then ſpeaking againſt the King, ſaying that he was altogether unjuſt and not fit to Reign, and he wonder'd he did not take example by his Father before him. and did really believe that he was a Papiſt in his heart, and intended to introduce Popery. I was ſometime after with him and
I told him one Haines had told me he had ſomething to diſcover about the death of Sir Edmond-bury Godfrey and ſeveral other things, and my Lord deſired to ſee him, and I brought Mr. Haines to his houſe, and he deſired him that what he had to ſay he would put in Writing, and he ſhould have a Pardon, and that if the King did deny it, as he dares not deny it, but if he does, we will riſe upon him and force him?

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: Had you any other diſcourſe, at other times?

sp.speaker: Mr Ivey.
sp.p: Yes, I had other diſcourſe but not to this purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: Was you frequently with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: I was frequently with him; he deſir'd at the time I was with him to bid Colledge to come to him, and I went and came again to Haines with inſtructions how to proceed, and I took his examination of him, and carry'd it to my Lord, and he deſired it might be explain'd what he meant by the Tall Black-Man, and ſays he, if he does mean the King, he muſt explain himſelf, and ſpeak of the King, or the Duke of York or the reſt, and if he does, we will take care of him as long as he lives, but unleſs he does we will do nothing for him, and I was with him with my Lord Shaftsbury, and my Lord Shaftsbury did exclaim againſt the King.

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: What words did he ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey.
sp.p: He ſaid he was altogether an unjuſtMan and not fit to Reign, and that he believed he was a Papiſt in his heart, and deſign'd to Introduce Popery, and therefore they deſign'd to depoſe him, and ſet up another in his ſtead?

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: Do you remember any diſcourſe of Richard the Second, at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: No Sir, I do not remember any thing of it.

div.p: Bernard Dennis Sworn.

sp.speaker: Sir Francis Withins.
sp.p: Pray tell the Jury what diſcourſe you had with the Earl of Shaftsbury at any time, and what it was.

sp.speaker: B. Dennis.
sp.p:
My Lord, I came upon a deſign to make cleer the Plot in General, as far as I have travell'd, as in Ireland, France, Spain, Maryland, Virginia and England, and upon that account I was brought before a Juſtice of the Peace, in Weſtminſter in November laſt, this time 12 month, and Examin'd before Juſtice Walcup, a Juſtice of the Peace, and from thence to the Committee of the Houſe of Commons, of whom Collonel Birch (I believe he is here) was Chair-man, and gave in my Evidence, and being called upon at the Tryal of the Earl of Stafford, I was commended as I ſuppoſe to the Earl of Shaftsbury, and upon the Account he ſent me word of it, by William Hetherington, who was then very intimate with the Earl of Shaftsbury to my knowledge; and William Hetherington
came to me ſeveral times, and he preciſely was my maintainer at that time▪ that is, to find me what ever I wanted, and provide me my Lodging, and carry me to ſome place where accommodation might be more better for me. Upon this account one time the Earl of Shaftsbury ſent to me, deſiring that I would wait upon him at his own houſe. I came to him, and there in the Gallery of his own houſe, walking very ſlowly he told me, what I gave in of the Plot in general was very good and ſufficient, but as to the Queen and the Duke of York, that I ſhould ſpeak more home and poſitive againſt them, at leaſt that I might be a corroboration to others in what they Swore againſt them; This was all at that preſent time, that the Earl of Shaftsbury ſpake to me, and he deſired me to go home to his Lodgings. With that I went home, and within a Month it may be, or thereabouts, he ſent for me again, by the ſame William Hetherington, and William Hetherington told me, that the Earl of Shaftsbury would ſpeak with me. So I came and Waited upon his Lordſhip at his own Houſe, and ſay's he, Mr. Dennis I underſtand that you are a Clergy man. Yes my Lord, ſaid I. And ſay's he, I would adviſe you to take a black gown, and I will preferr you to a Benefice, till ſuch time as this buſineſs is over; and, ſays he, at the end of this buſineſs I will not fail to preferr you to a better, and in the mean time I would adviſe you to take a black gown; and this was a little, as I remember, after the Parliament was Diſſolv'd at Oxford; and he ſent a Gentleman out of his own Houſe along with me, to a Doctor of Divinity living hard by Lincolns-Inn Fields, Dr. Burnet by Name, as I remember, and the Gentleman acquainted the Doctor what I was, and about what occaſion I came there; ſo the Doctor indeed diſcourſed with me very familiarly, and rend'red thanks to the Earl for me into his converſation rather then another's. What diſcourſe we had then was nothing to the matter, it was about matters of Conſcience, and Religion. But Mr. Colledge that was the Joyner here in Town, and Executed afterwards, being familiar with me brought me to one Mr. Ferguſon a Miniſter, as I ſuppoſe of the Presbyterian form, for he goes in their garb as near as I can tell, and Mr. Ferguſon at our firſt meeting was in Richard's▪ Coffee-Houſe, in an upper room one pair of ſtairs, and in ſome company; and Colledge going to him brought him aſide, and ſpake to him concerning me, and he came to me apart, and diſcours'd with me; from whence he brought me to a Bookſeller's Shop. and bought for me the Articles of the Church of England, and in all theſe diſcourſes there was a hand, as Colledge told me, of the Earl of Shaftsbury who did procure him, and ſent to Dr. Burnet to bring me that way. I do not deny neither, that I had an inclination before I left Ireland, and when I was in Spain, and when I was in France for to become a Proteſtant, according to the Laws and Rules of the Church of England. The force of what I have to ſay is this, The Earl of Shaftsbury one day after all theſe things were paſt, and after the Parliament were diſſolved at Oxford, diſcourſing with me in his own Houſe, Major Manley being in the ſame Room then, who lives beyond Tower-hill, he asked me what was the preſent occaſion I came to him there, and it was pretty early in the Morning, and the Earl had a Barber to trim him in his Room. I told him my occaſion was then, That I was ſomething low in Money, that I did a little want money at that time, and did not know to whom to ſpeak for any thing but his Lordſhip, and ſaid I came to tell you ſo. Well, ſay'd he, Mr. Dennis I have appointed Mr. Rouſe,
John Rouſe whom you know, for to give you and maintain you in money; go to him eſpecially once a week, and he will give you money. And, ſaid he, Mr. Dennis, what is the Number of your name in the Country as near as you can tell, how many are you? My Lord, ſaid I, to tell you exactly what number they be of, I cannot at preſent, but within a little time, I may tell you. I believe really there may be upon the matter 3 or 400 able men of my Name, in the County where I was born. Say's the Earl of Shaftsbury, Mr. Dennis, I would very willingly have you to adviſe thoſe of your name, and thoſe of your Friends for to be in a readineſs, when ever occaſion ſhall ſerve, and to ſtand by, if occaſion ſhould be, for to aſſiſt the Commonwealth of England; for we do really intend to have England under a Common-wealth and no Crown; and, ſay's he, we intend to live as we ſee Holland does, that is, to have a Commonwealth, and to have no Supream head, particular man, ſay's he, or King; nor owe Obedience to a Crown; and, ſay's he, we will extirpate the King, and all his Family as near as he can; and Mr. Dennis, ſay's he, I do admire that your Nation ſhould be ſuch Fools as they are, for it is very certain that King James, Queen Elizabeth, King Charles the Firſt, ſay's he, and the King that now is, does wrong you to very deſtruction; and, ſay's he, if you had been under a Common-wealth, the Common-wealth would take more pitty of your Nation, and the Gentry of your Nation, then any doe of them now, in this time wherein the King Governs, and upon this I doe count the Iriſh fools. This is all that I can ſay.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The King's Council declare they will call no more Witneſſes, for they think they have called enough already, and there are ſeveral of them that doe ſwear Words that are treaſonable in themſelves, if you do deſire to ask any of the Witneſſes any thing, you ſhall have them all call'd one by one.

sp.speaker: Fore-man.
sp.p: My Lord, we will walk up again, and Conſider what Queſtions to ask▪ and come again preſently.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papillon.
sp.p: It ſeems they will call no more Witneſſes then theſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Not againſt the Earl of Shaftsbury, being you are charg'd only with that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papillon.
sp.p: It is ſo my Lord, but we pray we may be ſatisfyed upon the Statute the Indictment is grounded, becauſe we may hear it read before we go up, becauſe your Lordſhip ſpeak's of two different Statutes, the 25th. of Edward, and you mention the Statute of the 13th. of this King; your Lordſhip in your diſcourſe to the Jury mentioned them both, we pray your Lordſhip to acquaint us upon what Statute it is grounded, whether upon both or one of them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look ye Gentlemen, this is grounded upon the Statute of this King, though there is enough to find an Indictment of Treaſon upon the Statute of the 25th of Edward the Third; that which is Treaſon within the Statute of the 25th of Edward the Third, is Treaſon within this Statute, ſo this is the more Copious Statute; for as I told you before, this Statute has enlarged that of Edward the Third in a great many Particulars; and therefore look ye Gentlemen, always conſider this, when one Statute contains the Matter of another, and inlarges it, the Indictment is always upon the laſt Statute, that being the more Copious Statute: But you are to Conſider both.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. Nor.
sp.p: The Indictment is Contra formam Statut'. and it being Contra formam Statut'. it may be underſtood, Statutorum or Statuti, ſo that all Statutes that may be the Foundation of this Indictment you may go upon.

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: We deſire to know whether any of theſe Witneſſes ſtand indicted or no.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look ye, Gentlemen, don't talk of this, but conſider with your ſelves, an Examination or Proofs concerning the Credibility of the Witneſſes is not properly before you at this time; for I muſt tell you, and inform you as to that, you are not to Examine properly here concerning the Credibility of the Witneſſes, that is not to be proved or controverted here before you, that is Matter, upon a Trial by the Petty Jury, for there the King will be heard for to defend the Credit of his Witneſſes, if there be any thing that can be objected againſt them; it is proper for the Priſoner to do that, you are only to ſee whether the Statute be ſatisfied, in having Matter that is Treaſonable, and having it witneſſed by two Men, by two Witneſſes, who are intended prima facie Credible, unleſs you of your own knowledge know the contrary; for otherwiſe, you muſt conſider what a diſadvantage this would be in all ſuch Caſes, if the Credibility of the Witneſſes ſhould be examined before the Grand Jury, where the King is not preſent, nor in a poſſibility of defending the Credit of his Witneſſes; the Priſoner or the Party Indicted is not here; that is a proper Objection when he comes upon his Trial; for all men are intended Credible, till there are Objections againſt them, and till their Credits come to be examined on one ſide and the other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papillon.
sp.p: My Lord, if your Lordſhip thinks good, I will beg this, I deſire your Lordſhips pardon, whether your Lordſhip doth not think that we are within the compaſs of our own Underſtanding and Conſciences to give our Judgment?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Your own Underſtandings and Conſciences, yes; but look ye, Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Mr. Papillon.
sp.p: If we are not left to conſider the Credibility of the Witneſſes, we cannot ſatisfie our Conſciences.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look ye, Gentlemen, you are to go according to the Evidence of the Witneſſes; you are to conſider of the Caſe according to the things alledged and proved, unleſs you know any thing your ſelves: But if any of you know any thing of your own knowledge, that you ought to take into Conſideration, no doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Very well, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The Grand Jury are to hear nothing, but the Evidence againſt the Priſoner; therefore for you to enter into proofs, or expect any here, concerning the Credit of the Witneſſes, it is impoſſible for you to do Juſtice at that rate.

div.p: The Jury withdrew, and the Court adjourn'd till 3 a Clock.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Let the Witneſſes be brought in one by one.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: We will firſt ask a Queſtion of Mr. Gwynn.

div.p: Mr. Gwynn.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Who put up the Papers?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gwynn.
sp.p: I put up the Papers my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Who went in with you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gwynn.
sp.p: None but my Lords Servants, I think, were there: But I put up the Papers my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, whoſe hand writing is that Paper of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gwynn.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: How did it come into my Lord Shaftbury's Cloſet?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gwynn.
sp.p: My Lord, this is a ſtrange Queſtion. Indeed, Sir, I can't tell; all the Papers that I found in that Cloſet I put into that Bag.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To ſatisfie the Jury, was the Paper in the Cloſet before you came there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gwynn.
sp.p: My Lord, it was certainly ••• re, for there I found it; I don't know the particular Paper, but all the Papers in that Bag were there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: From whom had you the Key?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gwynn.
sp.p: From my Lord Shaftsbury.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Don't you know, Sir, there was a Diſcourſe in the Parliament of an Aſſociation?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gwynn.
sp.p: Sir, I was not of the laſt Parliament. Sir, I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: You have not heard then, that there was ſuch a thing in Parliament concerning an Aſſociation?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gwynn.
sp.p: I have heard of an Aſſociation talked of.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Mr. Secretary, I would ask you ſome queſtions, if you did not know of a Debate in Parliament of an Aſſociation?

sp.speaker: Mr. Secretary.
sp.p: I was not preſent at the Debate; but there was a talk in Town of an Aſſociation.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Did not you hear of it in Parliament?

sp.speaker: Mr. Secretary.
sp.p: Indeed there was an Anſwer to a Meſſage from the Houſe of Commons that had ſome thing in it that did ſtrongly imply an Aſſociation; but this particular Aſſociation I do not remember to have heard propos'd.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Don't you remember in the Houſe of Commons, Sir, it was read upon occaſion of that Bill?

sp.speaker: Mr. Secretary.
sp.p: I heard ſuch a thing ſpoke of; but at the Reading of it I was not preſent, to the beſt of my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: What Date, Sir, was the Warrant for my Lord Shaftbury's Commitment?

sp.speaker: Mr. Secretary.
sp.p: I refer my ſelf to the Warrant, for that I do'nt know the Date.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Secretary, you muſt ſpeak about the time that it was▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Secretary.
sp.p: Sir, I was the man that had the honour to Sign that Warrant by which the Serjeant at Arms did Apprehend my Lord Shaftsbury, but what day of the Month I do not remember; and therefore I refer my ſelf, if you pleaſe, to the Warrant, and to the Serjeant at Arms.

sp.speaker: Foreman,
sp.p: What Month was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Secretary.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: About what Month?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: The beginning of July?

sp.speaker: Mr. Secretary.
sp.p: Sir, I do not remember the day preciſely, for I did not foreſee that Queſtion would be asked me; but I refer my ſelf to the Warrant, and that is beyond all doubt.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe all theſe Witneſſes that are examin'd, were examin'd before the Committee.

sp.speaker: Mr. Secretary.
sp.p: Sir, They were examin'd, and I was preſent at the Examination.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: All of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Secretary.
sp.p: I don't know whether all of them; but I am ſure I was at the Examination of ſeveral of them.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: How many, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Secretary.
sp.p: I can't tell truly how many.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Call Mr. Booth.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: He is not here, the Tipſtaff has him ſome where.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Is that Witneſs a Priſoner?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Booth is a Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Then call Mr. Turbervile.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Is Mr. Turbervile there?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Here is Mr. Booth come now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey.
sp.p: Put Turbervile out again.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Mr. Booth, you told me of a Diſcourſe that paſt between the Lord Shaftsbury and your ſelf, we deſire to know where it was, and when.

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: It was in Thanet-houſe, Sir, where he lived, about a week or Ten days before the Parliament ſat at Oxford.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: The preciſe time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: I cannot be more preciſe.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Who introduced you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: I think one Mr. Wilſon led me into the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Who was preſent when the Diſcourſe was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: None but He and I, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If we have theſe Noyſes, we will have every one of you put out of Court.
Mr. Att. General. Richardſon, Richardſon, Pray turn them all out; they are brought in on purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: It was not the firſt, ſecond, nor third time that I had waited upon the Lord of Shaftsbury.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: In what Room was it that my Lord ſpake thoſe words to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: It was in the Room he uſually ſets in, on the left hand as we come out of the long Gallery, I think we paſſ'd through a Room before it, Wainſcotted about, as I remember, and hung. I have been in that Room with him four or five times, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: After this Diſcourſe with you, how long was it before you ſpake of it to any body elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Truly I think I did not publiſh this Diſcourſe that my Lord and I had, from the time it was, till within this Seven or Eight weeks.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: You were never examined before then as a Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: No, Sir, I never was, nor no body will pretend it, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: To whom, Sir, did you give your firſt Information?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Sir, I ſent my firſt Information in writing to the Lords in the Council.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: By whoſe hand?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: By the hand of Walter Banes.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: You had ſeveral Diſcourſes with him; Had you eaſie Admiſſion, or was it with difficulty you came into his Company?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: I was admitted by the influence of Captain Wilkinſon at firſt, and ever after went with him, and had eaſie admittance and familiarity with him.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Was he with you every time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: No, not every time; he was not this time with me.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Did he talk to this purpoſe every time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Something to this purpoſe he did talk every time, but not ſo fully; for I was firſt acquainted with this Buſineſs of Oxford by Captain Wilkinſon, and I had a great deſire to underſtand it from my Lords own mouth, becauſe I would be ſatisfied in my Lord's Intereſt, as well as his Conduct.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what Education have you had?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: I have had the Education of a Gentleman, an Academical Education.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Were you ever in Orders?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Do you own your ſelf to be in Orders ſtill?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: How do you mean to be in Orders? I tell you I was in Orders; but I am not now Benificed.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Do you officiate as a Miniſter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Were you ever an Attorney's Clerk?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Or a Juſtice's Clerk?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Never; nor to no Mortal.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Were you ever Indicted for any Felony?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is a Queſtion not to be asked by any Jury-man of any Witneſs whatſoever: No man is bound to diſcover any thing of that Nature that is Criminal, concerning himſelf.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: If it be pardoned, my Lord, he may.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pardoned, or not pardoned, he is not bound to accuſe himſelf, nor to fix a Scandal on himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: No, my Lord, Nemo tenetur ſeipſum prodere.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Sir, we muſt not ſuffer ſuch Queſtions; I will tell you the reaſon: It is proper for a Priſoner that ſtands upon his Juſtification to object it, but then the Priſoner muſt prove it: It lies upon him to prove it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Mr. Booth, you told us of Fifty men that were Liſted under Captain Wilkinſon, Do you know any more of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: I never directly converſed with any other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Did you know any more of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: No, not directly I did not, but only by Captain Wilkinſon's Information.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: How many Stories was that Room where you talked with my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: One pair of Stairs, as I remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey.
sp.p: Was it the right hand as you came in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey.
sp.p: Was it the right hand or the left?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: I went into the long Gallery firſt, and ſtayed there about a quarter, or half an hour; and I remember very well I looked upon ſome Maps that were there, to divert my ſelf a while; and when I was called in, went out of the Gallery on the left hand, and went through another Room before I came into my Lord's Room.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Did you never hear my Lord ſpeak Treaſon in any Houſe but his own?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: I never had occaſion to hear this Diſcourſe from my Lord▪ but in his own Houſe; I never waited upon him in any other Houſe.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Was you never deſired to be a Witneſs againſt my Lord Shaftsbury?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Not till I intimated ſome thing of it.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Who was that too?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: That was to Mr. Banes, I told you before ſo.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: When he told me of his Buſineſs with the Yorkſhire Attorney Brownrigg, I did ſay again, I did not know what my Lord had done as to any thing of Iriſh-men, but I was ſure there was ſomething as to Engliſh-men, as to that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Did he propoſe any Reward, or any thing of that Nature?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Not a Farthing; for I think he had no Commiſſion to do it.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Are you acquainted with one Callaghan and Downing, two Iriſh-men?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey.
sp.p: Were you never in their Company?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey.
sp.p: Did you ever hear their Names?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: I don't know that I have.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Were you in their Company lately?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Not, as I know of. I do not remember either their Names or their Perſons, nor do I know them from other men.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Do you know one Mr. Shelden?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Do you know one Mr. Marriott?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: No, Sir: I have heard of one Marriott that did belong to my Lord Duke of Norfolk.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: When were you in his Company?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Never that I know of.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Has no body diſcourſed you from him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: No, no body.

sp.speaker: Foreman,
sp.p: Did you never hear of any Witneſſes he ſent to his Tenants?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: I have heard from Banes about Brownrigg, about Iriſh Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey.
sp.p: Did you never hear of any Iriſh Witneſſes ſent down by Mr. Marriott to the Iſle of Ely?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We gave you all the liberty in the World, hoping you would ask pertinent Queſtions, but theſe are Trifles. I did not expect that any wiſe men would have asked theſe Queſtions. Mr. Godfrey, was it to the purpoſe whether Mr. Marriott ſent any Iriſh Witneſſes to his Tenant, or no? What is that to this buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: My Lord, I have it under the hand of the Clerk of the Council.

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, Did any inform you that I had any Correſpondence with this man?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, you muſt ask no Queſtions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey.
sp.p: Mr. Booth, do you go under no other name but Booth?

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: No, nor never did in my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Booth.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot go in ſafety here for the Tumult.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Let the Officers ſecure him: Mr. Sheriff, look to him, that the man be ſecure and ſafe; I will require him at your hands elſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sheriff Pilkington.
sp.p: What ſhould I do?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Send your Officers to protect him, as becomes you, that he may be ſecured from the Rabble here.

div.p: Mr. Turbervile.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Mr. Turbervile, when you had this Diſcourſe with my Lord Shaftsbury, who was preſent with you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: One of his Servants; truly I cannot tell his Name.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: No body elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: I know the Name of none of his Servants, but Mr. Sheppard, I cannot remember any body elſe.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Did he carry you up to my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: It was he, I think, told me I might go in: I was in the Dining Room.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: What time was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: In the Morning.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: What time was it when you had this Diſcourſe with my Lord Shaftsbury?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: It was in February.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: What time in February?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: About the beginning; I cannot tell exactly to a day.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: How long was this before you communicated this to any body?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: It was about the Fourth of July.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Then you concealed it from February to July: Who did you Communicate it to firſt of all?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: The firſt Depoſition I gave was to Mr. Secretary.

sp.speaker: Foreman▪
sp.p: Which Secretary?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: Secretary Jenkins.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Pray what Room was it you had this Diſcourſe in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: Sir, It was the Room at the upper end of the Dining Room; I think they call it the Dining Room; at the upper end of the Room, and turns on the left hand where he lay.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: Did you meet with no body about the beginning of July, after my Lord's Commitment, and tell them when you were challenged, and told you were to be a Witneſs againſt him, As you were alive you knew no ſuch thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. General.
sp.p: My Lord, this is not to be allowed: This is private Inſtructions which the Jury are not to take.

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: No, Sir, it is not private Inſtructions. Did you not ſpeak ſuch words to William Herbert?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you had any Information concerning this to Mr. Herbert?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: My Lord, I have a long time ago. My Lord, ſuch a perſon did tell me ſo and ſo, and ſet down the day; and he then ſaid he was very angry with him for it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look ye, Gentlemen, what Diſcourſe you take up at random in every Coffee-houſe? Is that fit to be brought in when Treaſon is in queſtion againſt the King's Life? Are theſe Coffee-houſe Diſcourſes, do you think, ground enough for you to cavel at Perſons, becauſe you have heard this Diſcourſe in a Coffee-houſe?

sp.speaker: Foreman.
sp.p: My Lord, I never was in a Coffee-houſe in my life with Mr. Herbert; but he declared this to me ſome Months ago.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And you think this is ground enough for you againſt him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: My Lord, we only ask this Queſtion, whether he hath not contradicted this, or ſaid the contrary to any body elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: I do not remember that ever I ſpake one word to Mr. Herbert in my life; and I can give you one reaſon. For I was diſcarded by all the People of my Lord's Intereſt at that time; and if I had given under my hand that I had known nothing againſt him, I believe I might have been in their favour as much as before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Were not you one that Petitioned to the Common Council in London?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile▪
sp.p: I did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: And did not you declare then that you were tempted to witneſs againſt your Conſcience?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: I believe I never read the Petition: It was drawn by the Order of Mr. Colledge, by a Man that lives about Guildhall; by a Scrivener about Guildhall; and I ſigned that Petition, but never read it, nor knew what was in it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Richardſon, any you Officers, watch by thoſe men that make a noiſe, and bring me in one to make an Example.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: My Lord, I go in danger of my life, for the People threaten to ſtone me to death, and I cannot go ſafe to my Lodging.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: What was your deſign in ſigning that Petition? what did you look for?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: The deſign was that the City ſhould take care of us.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Were you in a poor Condition?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: Truly I was not very poor, though I was not over full of Money.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: It is a ſtrange thing that you ſhould Petition for Relief, if you were not in want.

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: We were told by ſome Members of the Houſe of Commons, that there was a Vote in the Houſe of Commons ready to paſs, that the City ſhould advance Money for the ſupport of the Witneſſes, and that we would Petition that they would anſwer the Deſign of the Parliament.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: What Members were they?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: It was a Member of the Houſe of Commons that told me ſo, I will aſſure you two of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Did never any body move you, or deſire you to be a Witneſs in this caſe againſt my Lord Shaftsbury?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: No body in my life. When I came to ſpeak the truth of what I knew, I did it voluntarily.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: You did it voluntarily?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: I did, I will aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Do you know any thing more than what you have ſaid here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: No, not one tittle.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Mr. Turbervile, I deſire to be ſatisfied in one thing, whether my Lord Shaftsbury was Committed before or after your Information?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I cannot tell poſitively, as to that point; but I believe it was before; I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Did you hear my Lord ſpeak theſe words in any other Room or Place?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: No, indeed, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: It was about the Fourth of July, you ſay, your Depoſitions were taken?

sp.speaker: Mr. Turbervile.
sp.p: About that time, I ſuppoſe the Fourth of July—I hope your Lordſhip will take care that we be not knock't on the head.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That we give in Charge to Mr. Sheriff; and ſee you do take care of the King's Witneſſes at your peril. It is a reflection, not only upon the Government of the City, to ſuffer theſe Diſorders, but upon the whole Kingdom: Therefore, Mr. Sheriff, look the Witneſſes come by no hurt.

div.p: Mr. John Smith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Mr. Smith, the Jury ask you a Queſtion, whether or no you did not uſe to go by the name of Barry?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Sir, what names I have gone by is not pertinent to this purpoſe; I tell you I have gone by ſeveral Names, as all Popiſh Prieſts do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Did you never go by the Name of Barry?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: It may be I might; I have gone by ſeveral Names, as all Popiſh Prieſts do.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ever go by the Name of Barry?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I did, my Lord; it is uſual for Popiſh Prieſts ſo to do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: What Religion are you of, Mr. Smith?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I am a Proteſtant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: How long have you been a Proteſtant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Many years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: When were you firſt Converted?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Firſt Converted?

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Ay, to the Proteſtant Religion: You ſay you have been one many years?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I have been a Proteſtant, and was perverted to the Popiſh Religion▪ and afterwards became a Proteſtant again.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Bring in one of thoſe men that make the noiſe. Cannot you bring in one of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: When did you receive the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I believe not above Three Months ago, as the Rector of Bow-Church will inform you: I have it under the Church-wardens hands in other places in London.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Have you been deſired to be a Witneſs, or did you do it voluntarily?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Never deſired, I declare it; I did it voluntarily of my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: When did you give in your Evidence firſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: Truly I cannot exactly tell when I gave it in; I did not keep an account of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: What Month?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: Was it before my Lord was Committed, or after?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith.
sp.p: I believe it might be a little after. Whether it was before or after, I cannot exactly tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: To whom did you give your Information?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: My Lord, they commanded the people to ſtone us to death.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who did?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: Several perſons, and when we were at the Tavern, Dr. Oates's man came out and gave the Rabble a Bottle of Wine, and bid them knock us down.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know what the mans name is?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates
sp.p: I know nothing of it my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is your mans name?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I keep half a dozen men, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I hope you keep no men to affront the King's Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: No my Lord, it is a miſtake, I know nothing of it, we went thither to refreſh our ſelves.

sp.speaker: M. Papilion,
sp.p: Mr. Smith, who did you give your Information to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: What Information? Mr. Papilion, The firſt Information.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: My Lord, am I to anſwer to theſe queſtions?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay Anſwer them, tell them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: My Lord▪ the Information I gave in to Secretary Jenkins, but I gave notice long before of what I intended to do to other perſons.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: When did you hear theſe words▪ ſpeak to the time exactly?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: Which words do you ask?

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Thoſe you mentioned even now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: Sir if you pleaſe, I know you take all in ſhort hand, if you ask me what words, I will tell you, for if I do not expreſs my ſelf in the ſame words as before, you will take hold of me.

sp.speaker: L. J. C.
sp.p: I will tell you this, this may be an ill queſtion, for he told you, he had diſcourſed my Lord Shaftsbury at a great many times, and that at ſometimes he ſaid theſe words, at other times other words, and for you to catch him upon a queſtion, it doth not ſhew a fair inclination.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: My Lord, under your Lordſhips favour, we only deſire to diſcover the truth, we are not for catches.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him then which of the words you would have him declare the time of, and he will tell you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Let him ſpeak his own words, it was about the time when Hetherington went thither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: Truly I will anſwer that as punctually as I can, the month or day I cannot well tell, but the perſon that came for me was major Manly; and he came to Bethels Club, what time that was, I cannot ſay, but if you pleaſe to inform your ſelves of thoſe Gentlemen that I name, I believe they will tell you Mr. Bethel was there preſent, and knew very well I went to my Lord Shaftsbury that night, and returned to the Club again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey,
sp.p: Was it in the Evening or the morning?

sp.speaker: Mr Smith,
sp.p: Mr. Godfrey, Clubs are uſually at night I ſuppoſe, you know that was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Where did you ſee my Lord Shaftsbury?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: It was in his Dining Room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Did you hear theſe words in any other place, or at any other time, or any Treaſonable words againſt the King?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you Gentlemen, he told you of ſeveral other words at ſeveral other times.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: But he ſaid all at his houſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, but at ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: I know Mr. Attorny, what the Gentlemen would be at very well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Anſwer them whether you did hear him ſpeak any words that you conceive Treaſonable at any other time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: I did not indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: In another place? Mr. Smith, I do ſay I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Did you petition to the Common Councel?

sp.speaker: M. Smith,
sp.p: No Sir I never did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Are you an Engliſh-man or an Iriſh man?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: Thats no matter, no more than if I were a French-man or a Dutch-man.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Give them an account whether you are an Engliſhman or an Iriſh-man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: My Lord, I beg your Lordſhips pardon for that, if I were an Iriſhman, whether thereupon my Evidence would be prejudiced.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you Mr. Smith, I do hope the Gentlemen of the Jury have more diſcretion among them all, than to think that an Iriſh-man is not a good witneſs, I hope they are not ſuch perſons.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: My Lord, if you pleaſe whilſt I was in the City amongſt them, I never petitioned to the City, I never had a farthing from them, nor ever ſpake to any for it, I never had any occaſion for it, but if I had, it is probable I have enough in England, and other places, without being beholden to your Common Council.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Will you ask him any more queſtions?

sp.speaker: Jury,
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Is Mr. Smith gone? I would ask him one word, we would fain know what allowance you have, or what you receive, if you have any allowance, from any body?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Nay, I know not from whom: I ask whether you have any from any body?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look ye Gentlemen, is that a queſtion that is pertinent? I wonder you will go to ſuch queſtions: we allowed you to ask queſtions your ſelves, becauſe we look upon you as men of reaſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: My Lord, I do not know but it may be a proper queſtion to ask him if he have any allowance from any man upon this account.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Upon what account?

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Upon this account, if he ſays he has none 'tis an anſwer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you intend your queſtion, whether he is bribed to give Evidence, if you mean ſo, ſpeak plain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: We ask if he have any allowance?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: You don't ask me how the 6 or 700 l. was made up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You that are upon your Oaths ſhould have a care what you do.
Bryan Haynes.
Mr. Papilion, Mr. Haynes, when did you give in your Information upon this matter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: Againſt the Earl of Shaftsbury, Sir? Mr. Papilion, Ay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: The day that I was taken by the Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: That was before my Lord was committed, was it not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: Yes Sir, it was before my Lord was committed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Did you ever make any other Information to a Juſtice of the Peace? Mr. Haynes, Not of my Lord of Shaftsbury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Nor touching this matter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: No not any Information upon Oath, I may have diſcourſed with a Juſtice of the peace.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Did not you give in an Information of a Deſign againſt the Earl of Shaftsbury?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: To none but to Secretary Jenkins.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: You underſtand the queſtion, whether you did give no Information of a Deſign againſt my L. Shaftsbury to ſome Juſtice of the peace?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: No no, to none but Mr. Secretary Jenkins.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You do not obſerve his queſtion, did you ever give to any Juſtice any Information of a Deſign againſt my Lord Shaftsbury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I did to Sir George Treby, I made Affidavit before him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: I think it was in March laſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: What was that deſign againſt my Lord Shaftsbury?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: The deſign was what Mr. Fitz-Gerrald told me, he told me he gave under his hand to the King, that the Earl of Shaftsbury did reſolve to ſet the Crown upon his own head, or otherwiſe to turn the Kingdom into a Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Fitz-Gerrald told you this, and ſo you made Affidavit of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: Yes, before Sir George Treby.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: What time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: It was before the Parliament met at Oxford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: So you ſay the words were, when were the words ſpoken that you mentioned?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: The words againſt my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: He ſpake them to me a little before I made Affidavit, I cannot tell poſitively the time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: That was before his Commitment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: Yes, yes, my Lord was committed in June laſt, this Affidavit was made in March laſt before the Recorder of London.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North, When you ask him about the Information of the deſign againſt my Lord Shaftsbury, he ſays that was in March laſt, and when you ask him about the evidence he gives now, that was the ſame day he was apprehended by the Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: About June you ſay it was, that you ſay you gave in the Information againſt my Lord Shaftsbury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: The Information I made againſt my Lord Shaftsbury was in June laſt, the 28th. as I take it of June laſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Where was it you had this diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: I had ſeveral Conferences with my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Did he every time ſay the ſame?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: The laſt time I ſpake with him was in Iron-monger-Lane, for Mr. Whitaker told me he would ſpeak with me, and he would fain have me explain my ſelf, what I did mean by the tall man I mentioned in the Narrative, and I went to the houſe, and they told me he was there, and I ſent up a Note, and he deſired me to come up; but I ſent word I did not care to come up, becauſe I would not be known, and ſo he ſent me word to meet him after Dinner, and when I came, my name is Haynes my Lord, ſaid I, and I led his Lordſhip by the hand and went in there, I had I believe a whole hours diſcourſe with him, and pray my Lord ſaid I, among other queſtions, what Religion is the King of? truly ſays he, Mr. Haynes he hath no more Religion than an horſe; for ſaith he, they ſay Sir, he was inclined to Popery, when he came firſt to England ſays he, he had a tincture of Popery, and was much inclined that way, but ſince he was degenerated from all the Principles of Chriſtianity, for he is juſt like a perfect Beaſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: This you ſay was in Iron-monger-Lane.

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: Ay Sir, at a Paſtery Cooks Shop.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: What time was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: After Dinner in the after-noon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: In June, or when?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: I cannot tell what time poſitively, it was about the time of the Trial of Fitz-Harris.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Was it the ſame time he ſpake about the D. of Buckingham?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: That was when I was with him at his own houſe, and deſired him not to expoſe me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: What time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: I cannot tell Sir, for I never thought I ſhould be called to an account for it, and I cannot keep an Almanack in my head, and I deſired them not to expoſe me to the King's fury, for I heard the King was diſpleaſed with me: no ſays he you are miſtaken, this is the beſt opportunity we can have, and if he will not give you a Pardon, we will raiſe the whole Kingdom againſt him in Arms, and then he makes himſelf the Maſter and Author of the Plot, and conſequently he muſt expect to be ruined, unleſs he grant you a pardon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Did you ever hear any other words than what you have now teſtified?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: Yes Sir, for I diſcourſed with him in Iron-monger-Lane a great while, and told him that our only and beſt way to have our ends of the King, was to raiſe a Rebellion in Ireland, and that I had relations and friends, and could get diſcontented Perſons enough, and his Lordſhip would do the work here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: What, did you propound a Rebellion in Ireland?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: I offered to go beyond Sea, and that now was the beſt time to raiſe a Rebellion in Ireland, and he ſaid that was not the beſt way, for they had other means to take, and ſo the diſcourſe was waved.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: And is that all?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: That is all I remember now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Do you know of any other place or time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: I was with him at his houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Were you ever a witneſs for my Lady Windham or againſt her?

sp.speaker: Mr. Haynes,
sp.p: No Sir, but ſhe arreſted me, becauſe I ſaid I lay with her.
John Macnamara.
Mr. Papilion, Mr. Macnamara, when was it you had this diſcourſe with my L. Shaftsbury, what is the time as near as you remember?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: In March and April laſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Twice then do you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Which is that that was in April?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: That was the laſt, the laſt diſcourſe was in April.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: To what purpoſe was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: My Lord ſaid that the King deſerved to be depoſed as much as King Richard the ſecond did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: In April you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: In April.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: When did you give Information of this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: I cannot exactly tell Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Repeat what you ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: That the King deſerved to be depoſed as much as King Richard the Second, and that he took the Dutcheſs of Mazarines advice in every particular, which was the worſt of Woman kind.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: What time in April was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: It was in the beginning of April.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: In his own houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Who was preſent?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: There was Mr. Ivey by.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: When did you make information of this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: I cannot tell, it was a good while ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Was it before his Commitment?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: Yes Sir it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: To whom did you give information?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: To the Secretary of State, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Which of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: Mr. Secretary Jenkins, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Did not you petition the Common-Council Sir, for relief?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I ſigned a Petition that was drawn up, but I did not ſee it till it was brought to me to ſign.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Did you read it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: No I never read it neither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Nor don't know what is in it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: No nor don't know the contents of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion.
sp.p: My Lord, in that Petition they ſay, they were tempted to Swear againſt their Conſciences, and that ſome of the Witneſſes had made ſhipwrack of their Conſciences; we ask them now, and they ſay, they do not know what was in the Petition: if we ſhould ask them who tempted them, and who thoſe Witneſſes were, that made ſhipwrack of their Conſciences, it would ſignifie nothing; for ſince they do not know what was in the Petition, it is in vain to ask them any more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mac.
sp.p: For my part, my Lord, I never ſaw it till it was brought to me to be ſigned, and do not know the contents of it; but I heard Mr. Colledge that was executed at Oxford, was concerned in promoting the Petition, by my L. Shaftsbury's advice.

div.p: Dennis Macnamara.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Dennis Macnamara, tell us how you were introduced to my L. Shaftsbury, when you had this Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: By my Brother, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: What, he that was here laſt?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: He introduced you?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: When was it?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: It was in March laſt, the latter end of March, or beginning of April.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Cannot you tell which of the months?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: No, I cannot be poſitive in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Who was by?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: There was Mr. Ivey.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: No body but Mr. Ivey?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: No body but Mr. Ivey and my Brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Where was it?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: It was in his own Dining Room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Were none of his Servants in the Room?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Are you ſure none of his ſervants were there?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing elſe, at any other time?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Nor in any other place?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: When did you give in this Information?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: I gave it in a good while ago, Sir, I cannot be poſitive.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Was it before my Lord was committed?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: Yes, a great while.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: To whom did you give it?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: I gave it to the Secretary of State.

sp.speaker: Jury,
sp.p: Cannot you remember how long it was before?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: No, I cannot at the preſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Which of the Secretaries?

sp.speaker: D. Mac.
sp.p: Secretary Jenkins.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: My Lord, I only propoſe, whether we may not ask whether he have not a pardon, for it would be a ſatisfaction to us for ſome reaſon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: Look you here Gentlemen, when the Priſoner makes exceptions to the Witneſſes, then it is proper, but here are no exceptions to the VVitneſſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: My Lord, we make no exceptions, but we muſt ſatisfie our own Conſciences, my Lord, that we muſt do, and that is very much, as we find the Credibility of the VVitneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North, Gentlemen, what do you mean that he ſhould have a pardon for?

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: For Crimes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: You muſt not ask him to accuſe himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: If he hath a pardon, he is in ſtatu quo; ſuppoſe, my Lord, ſome of them have been guilty of poyſoning, ſome of felony, ſome of robbing on the high-way, we do but ask them if they be pardoned?

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: A man muſt not be impeached, but where he may anſwer for it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: My Lord, if you do not give us leave, we muſt forbear then.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: I do not think it proper to ask.

div.p: Edward Ivey.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: The Diſcourſe that you had with my L. Shaftsbury, when was it, at what time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: It was a little after the ſitting of the Parliament at Oxford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: VVas it at more times than one?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: All the ſame Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: No, not the ſame Diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: The words that you ſpoke of, when was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: That was after the ſitting of the Parliament at Oxford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: About what time was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: It was about the latter end of March, or beginning of April.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: When did you make Information of this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: I cannot be poſitive in that neither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Before my Lords Commitment or after?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: A while before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: To whom did you give it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: To the Secretary of State.

sp.speaker: Foreman,
sp.p: Who was preſent when my L. Shaftsbury ſpake thoſe words?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: Both the Macnamara's, as I remember.

sp.speaker: Foreman,
sp.p: Who elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: Truly, I do not remember any elſe privy to our Diſcourſe, neither am I certain, that both the Macnamara's were there, one of them was there I am ſure of it.

sp.speaker: Foreman,
sp.p: What was the reaſon you concealed this Information ſo long, had you no inducement to make it at that time, how came you to do it then and not before? What was the reaſon, you ſay it was the latter end of April and May, my Lord was not committed for a good while after, here was two months time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: I am not certain how long a time it was before, but I made it as ſoon as I could.

sp.speaker: Foreman,
sp.p: I ask you, whether you know any thing either of words, or treaſonable actions, or any thing of my Lord of Shaftsbury, ſpoken or acted at any other time or place?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ivey,
sp.p: No, I have declared what I know, as to the particulars.

div.p: Bernard Dennis.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Mr. Dennis, in the morning you told me ſomething about the Diſcourſe you had with my L. of Shaftsbury, tell me when it was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: It was in April, 4 or 5 dayes after the Parliament was Diſſolved at Oxford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: In the beginning?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: In March, after the Parliament was Diſſolved at Oxford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: It was in March, and where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: In his own houſe, here in this town, 4 or 5 dayes after the Parliament was diſſolved at Oxford, immediately after he came home, I do not think he was at home 3 days before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Who was preſent with you then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dennis,
sp.p: There was in the Room Mr. Sheppard his Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Who elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dennis,
sp.p:
Some of his Servants, his
Pages I ſuppoſe, but whether they did hear this or no, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Did my Lord whiſper it, or ſpeak out?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dennis,
sp.p: My Lord is not a man of an high voice, but of a mediocrite voice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Did he whiſper it in your ear?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dennis,
sp.p: No, I was juſt by him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Who was in the Room beſides?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dennis,
sp.p: No body, only his Servants.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: VVhen did you make this information?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dennis,
sp.p: I made it in the month of June.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: In the month of June?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dennis,
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: Before my Lord was committed, or after?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dennis,
sp.p: Before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: VVho did you make it to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dennis,
sp.p: I made my information to the Secretary of State.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papilion,
sp.p: VVhich of them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dennis,
sp.p: Secretary Jenkins.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: VVhy did you conceal it ſo long?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: Becauſe I was in the City ſo long.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Did you ever go about to muſter your 400. men you had in Ireland, I ask you whether you did or no?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: Upon my word I did adviſe ſome of them to be ready.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: And did you provide them with Arms?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: Not I Sir, I was not able to do it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: VVhat Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: I am a Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: How long have you been a Proteſtant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: I have been a Proteſtant ſince Febr. laſt. And this I muſt confeſs, that when I was in Spain and France, my reſolution was to be a Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey,
sp.p: Mr. Dennis, pray who was in the Room when you were there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: The Earl of Shaftsbury Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey,
sp.p: VVho elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: Mr. Sheppard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Godfrey,
sp.p: VVho elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: I cannot name them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Godfrey, when another man asks a queſtion, you ſhould conſider what is ſaid, and not ask the ſame queſtion over and over again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: In what place in his houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: In his own Chamber, in the great Chamber, I do not know whether you call it the Hall or the Parlour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: VVas it above ſtairs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: Yes, it was above ſtairs, my Lord does not uſe to ſpeak with any below ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Is this all that you know, have you heard my Lord ſay any treaſonable words in any other place, or at any other time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: In the long Gallery, in his own houſe, at another time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: VVhy did not you ſay ſo before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: I did ſay ſo before, in the long Gallery he told me he would have a Common-wealth in England, and extirpate the Crown of England and the King of England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Is that all, ſpeak all your knowledge?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: He ſaid we ſhould all Iriſh-men conform our ſelves to a Common-wealth, and by that we ſhould get our Eſtates again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: I ask you if this is all you have to ſay?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember any more?

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: More than you ſaid in the Morning?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p:
He ſaid he would extirpate the King, and make England a Common-wealth, and that we were fools and ſilly folks that did not comply our ſelves to their factious party, and that we ſhould get our Eſtates, and that he would get me a black Gown and a Benefice, in the
mean time, and when all things were done he would prefer me to a better, and not only my ſelf but all that were of my name, and would ſtick to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: Then you have nothing more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: I never ſpake to him but in his own houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: All your Kindred are Papiſts, are not they?

sp.speaker: Mr. Den.
sp.p: No Sir, I cannot ſay ſo, but moſt of them are.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: VVho can ſay that, that queſtion no body can anſwer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look ye Gentlemen, now you have asked theſe queſtions, you had beſt go and conſider what evidence is delivered, and weigh well all thoſe things that have been ſaid to you, and you muſt conſider your duty, you are to enquire here, whether it be fitting for the King to call my Lord Shaftsbury to queſtion upon this account of treaſonable words.

sp.speaker: Mr. Papil.
sp.p: My Lord, we deſire before we go, that either the Law may be read, or we may have the Statute-book up with us.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The Statute-book was never denyed, but you ſhall have the Law read here: Firſt the Statute of the 25th. of Edward the Third, and then this laſt Statute.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: I would ſay one thing, becauſe I obſerve that ſome of you asked the queſtion, whether the Parliament did not debate about an Aſſociation: whether it related to that Paper or no, I am not certain, I hope you will conſider that Paper well, for my part I muſt needs ſay for my ſelf, I heard of it, but I never heard it read before, and never heard the contents of it; but it ſeems to me to ſhow what thoſe Officers were to do, for the ends of this Aſſociation, and one of thoſe ends as I remember (Gentlemen, I refer you to the Paper, and hope you will conſider it, you are men of underſtanding) I thought that one of thoſe ends was to deſtroy the mercenary forces in and about the Cities of London and Weſtminſter, and that the Government was to be by the major part of the Members of Parliament in the ſitting of Parliament, not with the King, but the major part of the Members of Parliament. Gentlemen I may miſtake, for I profeſs I ſpeak only out of memory; but it ſeems to me to be of great conſequence, and there is great matter to be preſumed upon it, it being found under Lock and Key in his Study: but I ſuppoſe my Lord Shaftsbury may give an account of it, but there is great preſumption upon it, it doth not import to be an Aſſociation by Act of Parliament.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: VVhen the Parliament was prorogued or diſſolved, then the major part of the Members in each County engage themſelves to follow their Command and obey their Order.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: Gentlemen, I hope you will conſider your Oaths, and give all things their due weight.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVill you have the Statute read?

sp.speaker: Jury,
sp.p: VVe will read it above.

div.p: The Jury withdrew to Conſider the Evidence, and returned the Bill Ignoramus, upon which the People fell a hollowing and ſhouting.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, let it be Recorded this hollowing and hooping in a Court of Juſtice.
